_exec_summary.SummaryText:
1.    Executive Summary

1.1.    Accidental Release Prevention and Emergency Response Policies
The management of Fresh Express is committed to maintaining a safe work environment.  A Safety and Risk Manager has been assigned to ensure that safe practices are followed in the specification and operation of systems involving hazardous chemicals.  This site has developed and trained an Emergency Response Team to ensure rapid and appropriate response to ammonia emergencies.  The site has specific and written evacuation, reporting, and response procedures in place to protect Fresh Express employees, the public, and the environment in the event of an ammonia release. 

1.2.    Stationary Source and Regulated Substance
The Fresh Express plant covered by this RMP is located at 1361 Southern Road, Morrow, Georgia. The facility receives lettuce and other produce to be processed, packaged for consumer use in various salad mixes, set for short-term storage, and transported and distributed from this site.
The regulated substance is anhydrous ammonia.  One fixed ammonia refrigeration system is used for refrigerating produce at various temperatures. The total charge to this refrigeration system is 62,000 pounds of anhydrous ammonia.  

1.3.    Release Scenarios
The worst-case release scenario considered for this process is a release of the volume of the single High Pressure Receiver (a maximum of (62,000 lbs) .  No administrative controls and mitigation measures were considered to limit the off-site consequence distance for this scenario.  The estimated distance to the toxic endpoint for the worst-case scenario is 2.8 miles.
The alternative release scenario considered for this process is a release of ammonia from a ruptured evaporator coil caused by thermal expansion due to double blocking of the line.  The largest-evaporator coils (EC-1 and EC-2) were assumed and a volume of 2,357 lbs of ammonia were used for release calculations.  No administrative controls or mitigation measures were consid

ered to limit the off-site consequence distance for this scenario even though line lockout/tagout (an administrative control) exists.  The estimated distance to the toxic endpoint for the alternative release scenario is 0.1 mile.

1.4.    Accidental Release Prevention Program and Chemical-Specific Prevention Steps
Prevention of accidental ammonia release at Fresh Express is accomplished through sound industry practice in the original ammonia refrigeration system design and construction, the specification and review of system modifications, and the day-to-day operation and maintenance of the system.  
This includes:
A?    Compliance with industry standards and codes in effect at the time of initial construction and modification
A?    Performance of a thorough Process Hazard Analyses (PHAs) at least once every five years using accurate Process Safety Information
A?    Implementation of Operating Procedures which have been reviewed by PHA
A?    Appropriate initial and refresher training of system operations and maintenance personnel  
A?    Performance of preventive and corrective maintenance according to system component manufacturer recommendations and pursuant to site wide hazardous energy lockout and hot work permit programs
A?    Application of established auditing, inspection, and pre-start-up review protocols
A?    Use of qualified contractors for work on the system
The detailed Ammonia System Release Prevention Program is contained in a supporting document (revised and updated May, 2010) which is maintained at the siteA?s Safety Office.

1.5.    Five Year Accident History
Between December, 2004 (the previous revalidation of the site program) and the present, no ammonia releases resulted in onsite or off-site injuries, deaths, or property damage, or off-site environmental damage, evacuations, or sheltering in place. However, the following ammonia-related incidents occurred:
A?    1/12/05 - There was a release of ~11 lbs in the pumper drum room from pump #2 on the #4 recirculator.  The leak w

as detected by maintenance personnel who alerted refrigeration personnel.  The unit was isolated and the ammonia (NH3) was drained. No evacuation was needed.  The unit was repaired and put back online.
A?    3/4/05 - There was a release of ~2lbs of NH3 vapor.  The leak was discovered by vendor technicians that noted an ammonia smell.  The vendor notified Fresh Express refrigeration technicians.  The production floor was evacuated.  The investigation showed a leak at the Air Handler Coil #12 in the salad processing area.  The unit was shut down, all NH3 was pumped out, thus stopping the release.  The production area was ventilated to clear the ammonia smell and then re-occupied.  The unit was repaired and put back online.
A?    12/26/06 - There was a release of approximately 20 to 30 lbs of ammonia during a PRV (Pressure Relief Valve) replacement on the Zone 2 recirculator.  The PRV was isolated via the three way valve.  When the PRV was loosened, operators noted a release.  The operators immediately proceeded to isolate the NH3 inlet valve, then decreased the suction pressure to the tank to help lower the pressure and slow the leak.  The room was ventilated and the employees were evacuated.  The operators were able to isolate the leak, replace the PRV and re-occupy the production area.  
A?    5/31/09 - There was a release of <5lbs of NH3 vapor from Zone 4 Chiller 16.  The ammonia odor was notice by personnel who informed refrigeration operators.  Investigation found a pinhole leak on the chiller plate.  Operators isolated and pumped NH3 out of chiller and stopped the leak.  No evacuation was needed.
A?    2/3/10 - There was a release of ~1lb of NH3 from Evaporator Coil Zone 1 Chiller 5 in the shipping area.  The leak was detected by plant personnel.  The investigation showed a small leak at the flange of the hot gas pilot.  The unit was isolated and the leak was stopped.  The area was ventilated to remove ammonia odor.  The cause was a combination of a failed gasket and an und

er-torqued flange.
A?    02/07/10 - There was a release of <5lbs of NH3 vapor into ammonia compressor room from compressor #3.  The leak was located at the selector valve.  The leak was detected by NH3 sensors that alerted operators via flashing light.  The operators shut the compressor down, located and isolated leak, ventilated the space, replaced the leaking valve and put the compressor back online.  The preventative maintenance procedures will be updated to include periodic valve inspections.

1.6.    Emergency Response Program
Fresh Express has developed an Emergency Planning and Response document to ensure adequate preparedness with rapid and appropriate response to ammonia release emergencies.  The plan is maintained at the siteA?s Safety Office and reviewed annually.  The document describes outside agency notification procedures in the event of an ammonia release, provides detailed evacuation procedures, and includes response procedures for the mitigation of ammonia releases. 
The site has an Ammonia Emergency Response Team trained to use the Incident Command System organizational framework.  This is also described in detail in the planning document.

1.7.    Planned Changes to Improve Safety
Based on the Revalidation Process Hazard Analysis (PHA) conducted on March 17 and 18, 2010 the following adjustments are planned to ensure continued safe operations:


#    Actions    PHA Table
Item #    Assignee    Due Date /
Status
1.        Add signage prohibiting combustible storage near the HPR.    9    Vann    
2.        Install PRVA?s on the condenser to prevent an excessive overpressure of condenser due to equipment shut down.    56    Vann    
3.        Develop a procedure for a monthly verification that diffusion tank is adequately filled.    77    Vann
